subject: Education
title: The Zeigarnik Effect: Why Unfinished Tasks Haunt You
description: A micro-lesson that makes The Zeigarnik Effect: Why Unfinished Tasks Haunt You usable.

hook.text: A waitress remembered every unpaid order perfectly. The moment a bill was settled, she forgot it. Bluma Zeigarnik

buildup.text: The Zeigarnik Effect: unfinished tasks occupy working memory more than completed ones. The brain keeps them active.

discovery.text: This is why cliffhangers work and why you can't stop thinking about an unsolved problem â€” your brain won't let go.

twist.text: Teachers can exploit this: end a lesson mid-problem. Students keep thinking about it after class â€” involuntary studying.

climax.text: The Zeigarnik Effect proves that the best way to make students think is to leave something unresolved. Closure kills

punchline.text: The best lessons don't end with answers. They end with better questions.

quiz.question: What is the Zeigarnik Effect?
options: Unfinished tasks stay active in memory more than completed ones
